thread.title: Morocco eyes boycott of Swedish companies over disputed Western Sahara
thread.title_full: Morocco eyes boycott of Swedish companies over disputed Western Sahara

author: Aziz El Yaakoubi
title: Morocco eyes boycott of Swedish companies over disputed Western Sahara
text:
The Moroccan government has suspended the opening of the first IKEA store outside Casablanca. Photo: AP
Rabat, Morocco: Morocco is considering a boycott of Swedish companies operating in the North African kingdom because of Sweden's position on a dispute over Western Sahara.
Morocco has controlled most of territory since 1975 and claims the sparsely populated stretch of desert, which has offshore fishing, phosphate reserves and oilfield potential, as its own.
The government said Sweden has been campaigning to boycott products from Western Sahara and from international companies with a presence there.
Work in progress: Morocco' first IKEA store earlier this week. Photo: AP
"We are heading toward a boycott of Swedish companies according the principle of reciprocity after similar campaigns to boycott Moroccan companies," a statement issued after the weekly cabinet meeting said.
Advertisement Sweden and other Scandinavian countries have backed Western Saharan self-determination â€“ a movement led by the Algeria-backed Polisario Front, while France and Spain have been accused by activists and human rights organisations of supporting the Moroccan line.
Swedish Minister for Foreign Affairs Margot Wallstrom said Sweden's entire policy on Western Sahara is the subject of an internal review.
Prince Moulay Rachid, of Morocco, speaks during the 70th session of the United Nations General Assembly at UN headquarters on Wednesday. Photo: AP
"The government does not want to pre-empt this examination. Therefore, the issue of recognition is currently not on the table," she said.
A spokesman for the ministry also said that Sweden had no boycott against exports from Morocco.
The Moroccan government did not give details on how the boycott would be implemented or say whether it knew which Swedish companies could be affected.
"We are considering it, but we hope Sweden would review its position on the Moroccan Sahara," Mustapha Khalfi, Communication Minister and government spokesman, told Reuters. "That's all I can tell you right now."
However, Moroccan authorities have already blocked the opening of IKEA's first store this week, citing a lack of permits.
Swedish-labelled companies have been operating in Morocco for decades, including Geely-owned carmaker Volvo, H&M and Volkswagen-owned Scania.
Reuters
